bestBHT.bht: The Lord's work is evident, as the events described are attributed to Him. This is reminiscent of similar accounts found in Matthew 22:15-22. The Greek feminine form of this may suggest the exaltation of the Messiah, possibly influenced by the Hebrew original. The verse underscores the marvelous nature of the Lord's actions, fulfilling prophecies like Psalms 118:22. Despite mistreatment and death by the Jews, the Messiah's exaltation holds great significance.

Marvin Vincent: The Lord 's doing [παρα κυριου] . Lit., from the Lord.
Archibald T. Robertson: This (αυτη). Feminine in LXX may refer to kephal (head)...
...or may be due to the Hebrew original zoth (this thing)...
...which would be neuter τουτο in a Greek original, a translation Hebraism.
John Gill: This was the Lord's doing, and it is marvellous in our eyes."
That is, the exaltation of the Messiah, after he had been so ill treated, and at last put to death by the Jews.
These words are a continuation of the passage cited out of Psalms 118:22.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse highlights that the Lord's hand is at work in the events described. This echoes similar accounts in Matthew 22:15-22. The use of the feminine form of this in the Greek may refer to head, indicating the exaltation of the Messiah. It may also reflect a Hebraism in the translation from the Hebrew original. Ultimately, this verse affirms the marvelous nature of the Lord's actions and their fulfillment of prophecies, specifically referencing Psalms 118:22. It emphasizes the significance of the Messiah's exaltation despite previous mistreatment and his eventual death at the hands of the Jews.

The Lord's work is evident in the events described, as it is said to be from the Lord. This is reminiscent of similar accounts in Matthew 22:15-22. The Greek feminine form of this may imply the exaltation of the Messiah, serving as a translation Hebraism. This emphasizes the marvelous nature of the Lord's actions, fulfilling prophecies like Psalms 118:22. The verse underscores the significance of the Messiah's exaltation, despite previous mistreatment and eventual death at the hands of the Jews.
